dt: {bc}to furnish a justifying analysis or explanation
{bc}to be the sole or primary factor

dt.t: The left fielder {wi}accounted{/wi} for all three putouts.

dt: {bc}to bring about the capture, death, or destruction of something

dt.t: Enemy fighters {wi}accounted{/wi} for two of the bombers.

et: Middle English {it}accounten, acounten, accompten{/it} "to count, compute, evaluate, give an account of," borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acunter, acompter{/it}, from {it}a-{/it}, prefix forming transitive verbs (going back to Latin {it}ad-{/it} {et_link|ad-|ad-}) + {it}cunter, compter{/it} "to {et_link|count:1|count:1}"
shortdef: to furnish a justifying analysis or explanation —used with for
to be the sole or primary factor —used with for
to bring about the capture, death, or destruction of something —used with for

dt: used to say that all the people who are supposed to be at a place or event are there

dt.t: The students are {it}all present and accounted for{/it}.

shortdef: —used to say that all the people who are supposed to be at a place or event are there
